column1: This variant is now being detected as Linux/Lupper.worm.a ."
Sentence 2,A separate strand of the worm exhibiting identical behavior has been detected as Linux/Lupper.worm.b .
Sentence 3,The Lupper worm variants spreads by exploiting web servers hosting vulnerable PHP/CGI scripts.
Sentence 4,At least one variant has been identified as a modified derivative of the Linux/Slapper  and BSD/Scalper worms from which it inherits the propagation strategy.
Sentence 5,The worm blindly attacks web servers by sending malicious http requests on port 80.

Sentence 6,"If the target server is running one of the vulnerable scripts at specific URLs and is configured to permit external shell commands and remote file download in the PHP/CGI environment, a copy of the worm could be downloaded and executed."
Presence of one or more the following files:
One or more of the following ports are listening/sending:
This worm spreads by exploiting specific PHP/CGI script vulnerabilities that could be hosted on the following URLs:
These URLs are related to these vulnerabilities:
XML-RPC for PHP parseRequest() Function Arbitrary PHP Code Execution (CVE-2005-1921)
AWStats CONFIGDIR Parameter Arbitrary Command Execution   (CVE-2005-0116)
WebHints Shell Command Injection Vulnerability (CVE ID 2005-1950)
Users of these products are advised to contact the respective vendors for the updated patch information."
Sentence 8,Other malwares have reportedly been detected in recent penetration incidents concerning these vulnerabilities.
Sentence 10,"Both threats can be detected since DAT versions 4417 (December 29, 2004) and 4604 (October 13, 2005) respectively."
AVERT recommends to always use latest DATs and engine ."
Sentence 12,This threat will be cleaned if you have this combination.
